medium: Transparent light green glass; no impurities
dimensions: pres. h. 26.5 cm, max. diam. 7.44 cm (10 7/16 x 2 13/16 in.)
creditline: Gift of Robert D. Huxley, Class of 1964, and Mrs. Huxley, in memory of Pete and Jane Breene.

texts.textentryhtml: Mouth almost completely closed; neck conical; rounded shoulder; everted conical body, tapering to a point. Pair of vertical strap handles from shoulder to upper neck, where a coil of the same color is wound.
Given to the Museum by Robert D. Huxley and Mrs. Huxley

bibliography.boilertext: Anastassios Antonaras, Fire and Sand: Ancient Glass in the Princeton University Art Museum (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Art Museum, 2012)
bibliography.citation: Anastassios Antonaras, Fire and Sand: Ancient Glass in the Princeton University Art Museum (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Art Museum, 2012), cat. no. 195 (illus.)

bibliography.boilertext: Allen Rosenbaum and Francis F. Jones, Selections from The Art Museum, Princeton University, (Princeton, NJ: The Art Museum, Princeton University, 1986)
bibliography.citation: Allen Rosenbaum and Francis F. Jones, Selections from The Art Museum, Princeton University, (Princeton, NJ: The Art Museum, Princeton University, 1986), p. 49 (illus.)

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 1983," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 43, no. 1 (1984): p. 18-42.
bibliography.citation: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 1983," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 43, no. 1 (1984): p. 18-42., p. 41 (illus.)

displayperiod: Roman Imperial Period, ca. 30 BCE–476 CE
caption: Roman Imperial Period (ca. 30 BCE–476 CE), 1st century CE, Pointed amphoriskos. Transparent light green glass; no impurities; 26.5 x 7.2 cm. Gift of Robert D. Huxley, Class of 1964, and Mrs. Huxley, in memory of Pete and Jane Breene. (y1983-2)
